title: So.cl: An Interest Network for Informal Learning
segmentation: Hello everyone yeah social SO dot CL is how it's spelled so this is an experimental interest network that came out of the lab that I work at Fuse Lab where we focus on future social experiences.
So I wanted to give you some background described social for you and then talk about a study that we did.
I'm looking at it to use for informal learning.
So I think we can all agree that the Internet has had a really powerful effect on our day-to-day lives, in part through through searches and search engines.
Through these tools, we actually have access to the entire world of information and knowledge.
Their current estimates that there are about 3 billion searches a day on line.
Just give you a sense of scale.
There are 7 billion humans on the planet, so it's really amazing.

And has had a really transformative to be transformed the way that we think about information and knowledge and learning in particular you can characterize, characterize the effect by particularly interested in so that the democratization of knowledge that is a lot of education and learning is actually occurring outside of formal institutions, were not learning from experts in ivory towers.
A lot of people, in fact, are learning from their peers on line, in learning communities, and this.

This is actually very meaningful because it gives people increase access to learning opportunities that they would normally have, either because they don't have access to these formal institutions or they don't have access to that knowledge from their immediate circle.
A lot is there in the past five to 10 years, there have been a lot of really rich learning communities on line.

The majority of them were the most active or rich rich, rich experiences, more self sort of more tech savvy, self learning communities such as the maker communities or DIY Instructables which hopefully some of you are familiar with.
But we're particularly interested in, well, how can we bring these experiences through the more average user for the day today?
Activities.
Or interests.
And this is where motivation is actually really important consideration.
What is going to motivate you to spend your free time going on line learning?
And this is where we think that social media can actually be a really powerful for us.
We can really leverage social media because learning is inherently social.
It's social and that through your connections to people, you're inspired to learn your trying to spend time learning.
You're inspired about what to learn, but also your social environment can help scaffold the learning process.

So through social media or primary argument is that through social media we can give people that sense of connection to people in their extended networks that really help motivate them to learn new topics.
Are not otherwise available to.
No, there's certainly been a lot of work in this area.
I'll briefly highlight some search alot of search, research and technology.
Is it really been sort of thinking of it as information seeking behavior online?
But there is some work looking at.
Well how is search social?
Ticular one paper that I liked was from Evans and she looking at how it's actually is very social.
The forwarding processor, like foraging for information, but also the sense making process like how do we take all this information and make it coherent and meaningful?
But nonetheless, search tools tend to be designed primarily as an individual solitairy experience.

There have been some experiments in social search social tagging systems, but they tend to focus primarily on how do we improve the quality of search itself rather than thinking about, well, how are we using the experience that connect people around information?
Again, I mentioned earlier there are a lot of online learning communities on line.

In fact, Jenkins characterized this as the remix or participatory culture because so many people are putting content online and sharing it with each other and building knowledge communities around that.

But these do tend to be reasonably well communities with people who, with high barriers to entry, you actually have to create something and to participate actively where members are really already highly motivated to learn.
So on the other end of the spectrum, there are a lot of what was recently been characterized as interest networks.
These are public asymmetrical networks focus on broadcasting information such as blogs, Twitter, Pinterest, Tumblr.
You could always think of these as interest network.
So there are a lot of people who are broadcasting consuming information and that's really the primary activity or the primary reason that you're going to be connecting with people.
And these are really good for that.
More sort of lightweight sharing and broadcasting experience and serendipitous discovery.
But these systems haven't been directly integrated effectively with search.
Which brings us to social.

So the core idea behind social is how can we integrate the search experience where we have access to the entire world of information with also the sharing and networking experience and hopefully through that enable informal discovery and learning around search topics.
And so I know a lot of you on your laptops, and so I want to encourage you to try it now while you're listening to me if you want to.
I put the link in here www.so.cl.
I'm really excited because we just made it publicly available.
It was in private release as of last December, but we just made it publicly available a month ago.
So you can go try it if you want to.
So how does it work?
It's sort of structured similar to Facebook and that you have a feed in the middle and in this feed are the posts that people have created.
At the top is searching posting experience.
We'd start searching in there and you aggregate around that and then posed to the central feed on the left or feed filters so you can filter to everyone people I follow.
You can filter by interest and then on the bottom left you can see are the people and this has a very Twitter.
This is a Twitter model so I follow you.
I follow me.
We don't necessarily.
I don't have.
We don't follow each other synchronously, symmetrically the way you doing face.
As far as the post building experience, what you do is you type a search.
You get your search results and this is using Bing that is Microsoft.
I have a combination of images or pictures and you just essentially click on these Adam to the post, add a comment, tag it and it's added to the stream.
And I should.
I want to know that this is a very public experience, so everybody gets to see everything that everybody does.
You can filter, but it's all public.
So again, from this interest networking perspective, what are the goals help people find each other around common interests?
Hope you will be inspired by new interests they wouldn't have otherwise been exposed to, and then learn from each other around these shared interests.
I'm really interested also in this sort of collaborative elaboration on interest, so building on each others or extending what other?
We're thinking and so just just to give you an example.
Here.
So I posted a message about Japanese Bento.
Someone else responded with another post about Ben to Arjun.
There's another post about sushi art.
She can kind of see there's this elaboration of a theme.
And see that if someone posted about me as Yuki Bento, and Mizuki is the artist who created that tutorial.
Cartoon.
As you can see, this was elaboration or riffing around around an idea.
Era theme.
So before we released social, even as a private beta, we did a deployment study.
With 33 University of Washington students and we had two goals.
One we wanted to see the community with a target, target users, and so we're imagining student aged people who are reasonably tech savvy, probably.
And you get them in there and building some content before we made it public.
But also we wanted to study their existing learning practices so we can really see how would social fit into the ecosystem of their existing technology using behaviors around learning.
But then also how might they then integrate social as an informal learning tool?
So I'll be spending the next half of the talk described.
I studied you.
We use a mixed methods approach, so I'm a quantitative social psychologist.

Mahala have collaborated with me on this and she is more of an ethnographic qualitative approach, and our goal was really to sort of triangulate using these different methods so we can develop a really rich picture of what's happening with this student group.
So we had a focus group where they came onboard.
They fill out a questionnaire that talked about the demographics and current practices, so discussion.
And then ending with demo and then instructions for use of social.
ESO dot CL they are instructed to you social or try at least to use social as your primary search engine for an entire month.

We have the complete briefly weekly questionnaires, which is more about sort of helping us figure out the more usability questions, how to improve the experience we instrumented the system so we can track what they actually did.
Weeks three to four.
We did these well.
I want in one semi structured interviews.
Again, about their learning experiences and their use of social and then we had them do a final wrap up questionnaire.
The participants, again a student body and it is reasonably reflective of the student body at the University of Washington.
For example, there's a pretty high Asian percentage at the University of Washington.
A mix of sophomores, juniors, seniors, lot of them.
Part time jobs.
And so for incentive is a very standard practice at Microsoft.
We gave them a free piece of Microsoft software to motivate them to participate in this study and the stipend for ongoing participation over that month.
So first I want to describe you just a little bit more to the background, like what were the existing practices around informal learning.
And then I'll talk about social in particular.

What was really interesting to observe here, and I know a lot of you are academic professors and you interact with students every day, but from the perspective of someone who works at Microsoft is not in the academic environment, and some of this is very surprising to us that students are spending so much time online every day.
Cording about 4.6 hours per day for social activities in 3 1/2 or informational activities.
So in research information seeking on line there really always on in other words.

We asked him how important are the following types of technologies and communicating and sharing with people in your life about the topics that you care about, and you can see email and social networking sites were very important, as was instant messaging.
And in our in our interviews we should pursue this a little bit.
You know what does it mean that you spend so many hours and a lot of it is because they're on their phone and they carry their phone around with them every day during the day.
And they're constantly engaged to their phone.
We also asked want to get sense of where, where, where do you learn now like when you need to learn something new.
You know for work or class or your personal interests, like where do you go like?
What are your primary resources, websites on the Internet keep emerged as the most important resource, but also people that they know face to face.

So people are still going to their friends and their family and their their fellow students to learn more about a particular thing of interest there also using their extended networks online and sadly.
Libraries in bookstores are far, far fall behind, far behind.
We're also interested.
OK, we know for collaboration we're using collaboration, in particular with your fellow students.
Again, this surprise me, but cell phones are extremely important in interacting, collaborating around school, Ann.
Facebook also very important, followed shortly by email.

So we were trying to get a sense for how much do you kind of weave in and out of these tools and technologies online offline media, not media, and so so we asked them to describe a learning pathway in the initial focus groups, but also in the one on one interviews afterwards.
By that, you know from the moment you were sort of interested in the idea to the moment that you felt like you had wrapped up on that learning topic.
What was your path for learning?
And then we coded these each point along his pathway for whether or not it is a content only source, or if there is a social interaction involved.
So again, how much are people integrating with social interactions into their learning experiences?
So if an example here is my friend told me in person about stabbing in hometown, I wonder if this is a big issue.
So I search for it wasn't insert by found on the news tab.
Paraphrasing, so I clicked on different links to see if they are the same, and so in this case we coded.
My friend told me as this is a personal interaction that was face face and they searched news tabs and this is a content only source.
And again, because these are sort of pre measures, we found that 69% of the pathways described did involve at least one stop that was a social interaction.
43% went from a personal interaction to a content only source.
26% from a content only source through more personal interaction and I provide some examples here.
So I learned about Steve Jobs death from a friend on Twitter.
And then I checked Bloomberg for potential impact.

I wonder if this is a big issue, so I search for it wasn't surge but then it got.

I'm posting, everyone is going to see it, so it's really I'm posting is saying something about me and so I'm actually really curating the experience.
There's certainly any number of examples of people discovering each other around common interest in social and learning new information from each other.

Between.
What we wanted to do.

And how does it compare to their primary social network?
So the for most people, the primary search engine with Google and the primary social network with Facebook.

We did find that yes, students are already very heavily employing certain social media tools for learning informal learning online.
It is very social and incorporating social media and the pathways really do.
Even out of these personal interactions.
Pure content sources both online and offline.

With so, so we're seeing this integration of sharing around search, but really is much more for this sort of serendipitous informal learning around personal interests and less about more sort of serious heavyweight learning topics.
And based on this study, we experience a real shift in how we were conceptualizing the system.
You know less as I mentioned earlier.
Less on social search like I'm the primary activities search and then sometimes social to more interest based networking.
So people would definitely have this sort of self presentation self expression.
Experience around around there searches that impacted use.
And again, social became interested in the learning process at the discovery, foraging, and sensemaking levels, and there's more discussion about that in.
Paper so you know, I think it's really interesting.
I imagine that a lot of technology companies really struggled with this, particularly networking networking companies that there's real tension between.

If you have a public network like this on your goal is discovery and collaboration, the features that are going to enable really serendipitous discovery and broadcast sharing around interest in building a network and growing it are actually pretty different than the features that are going to optimize a more heavyweight controlled collaboration that requires more private messaging.
And groups, and so that's something that we are considering as a team with social units and experimental project as we go forward.
Do we want to optimize for this?
You know, make it big and lots of users, but a more shallow interest sharing and discovery.
Or do you want to optimize for deeper conversation and collaboration?
In which case we're going to need to integrate private messaging and groups.

So for our next steps we are very actively engaged in the process of growing the community and having a lot of fun learning from the process, thinking about what features do we need to integrate or more features we need to integrate interest discovery and collaboration, and then also a really common requests that people want and mobile experience we, you know, I can't remember if that was here earlier, but people are reporting about a third of their Internet time is through the mobile is through the mobile phone.
OK, any questions?
So a lot of times when I've looked at social link sharing systems, people adopt different roles.
This is really weird.
I hear myself and hear myself.
So some people like to be information gatekeepers.
They rush out and look for new things because they want to be the person who shares stuff and other people are collectors.
Do you find that kind of role playing or role adoption and social?
You know, so I mean, now that we have the system out, there is actually a lot of data that we've been playing with, and we did a factor analysis looking at types of users.
And yes, there's a content creators.
Is 1 category actually socializers we're calling them is another category, so the commenting and liking and following this kind of another type of person.
And then there is the browsers people who don't engage at either level, but they really actually present in that they're looking and browsing and clicking.
And there are those are.
Reasonably orthogonal sets of behaviors.
OK, one more question.
So I had a similar question to the one before.
Have you looked at Facebook use as well as social use?
I guess so is there to do.
People interact with the same set of friends as they do on Facebook, or do they form more interest based communities that are different from their social communities on Facebook?
Did you find any evidence for differentiation in that respect?
Yeah, it's not like it's not like Facebook.
At all, people are not connecting with people primarily around around pre existing social relationships.
It is primarily around common interests.
OK, but that with that said.
When we ask people who disengage when they come in and they spend time in the system, they don't believe they'll come back like the main reason for that is because their friends are not there.
So I do think that people want to learn and they want to have information and network around information, but they still want to do that with their friends.
Alright.
